data.text:
The last few days have been a bit of a blur for me, as any good Englishman would do, I celebrated the Royal wedding with beer, good food and DIY.

But now, I live in a republic and I am happy to be in this republic, but Poland once had a monarchy and early this morning with the aid of Wikipedia and Norman Davies, I set about finding the three most Kick-ass Polish Monarchs.

1- Boles≈Çaw I Chrobry

Born in 967, Boles≈Çaw is the kind of guy you either rate or hate. Many people think he liked to fight a little too much and this overzealous battle nutter of a king caused nothing but serious fiscal problems for the Polish people. However, I disagree. Boles≈Çaw was the sort of king no one messed with, Boles≈Çaw wasn‚Äôt afraid to fight both the Germans and the Russians at the same time. Boles≈Çaw even sent crack troops to help his nephew Canute in his conquest of England. Look at the map and appreciate the extent of his kick-ass abilities. As for his poor financial abilities, in 967 what else are you going to spend your money on? if not on battling and general war-mongery?

Small man syndrome?

2 ‚Äì W≈Çadys≈Çaw I the elbow-high / the short arse

In 1138, the not so bright Polish king Boles≈Çaw III Wrymouth left Poland divided up into principalities. W≈Çadys≈Çaw was born in 1260, inherited some land and through a little good fortune inherited some more and in 1304, decided to take upon the arduous task of re-uniting Poland. To do so he would need to fight a few Germans, please some nobles and twist the arm of the pope. However by 1320, W≈Çadys≈Çaw had returned Poland to the point in left off in 1138 and left the basis and foundations for future Kings to build Poland into one of the greatest European empires.

Polish ‚Äì Lithuanian Commonwealth 1686

3- Jan III Sobieski ‚Äì

A few hundred years later and Poland, through the help of a union with Lituania had become one of the most powerful countries in Europe, but it desperately needed stability and Sobieski gave it just that. Sobieski rocks because he was a more than good military commander who beat the Turks black and blue in the 1683 Battle of Vienna. He was such an able military commander that he controlled not only Polish forces in the battles but also German and Austrian troops. He was so impressive, other European monarchs nicknamed him ‚ÄòThe saviour of western civilization‚Äô ‚Äì what a nick name! ‚Äì oh and Sobieski Vodka is named after him.

Of course, these are just my opinions but I do love reading about Polish kings and Polish history in general. For anybody who would like to know more about Polish history I‚Äôm sure any British Council libraries will have copies of Norman Davies‚Äô work about Poland ‚Äì I specifically recommend ‚ÄòHeart of Europe‚Äô because it‚Äôs more easy going than the immense two tome ‚ÄòGod‚Äôs Playground‚Äô

This must be the number one most common question people ask me and it‚Äôs an impossible question to answer, second most common question is probably, ‚Äòhow much money do I NEED to earn in Poland‚Äô which again is impossible to answer because I‚Äôm not you and you will need a different sum of money to live on than me but nevertheless I do give some advice

When I moved to Poland I made a whole lifestyle change and promised myself to start again. Out with the old and in with the new so to speak. I decided not to be dependent on a car and not to be dependent on credit. After making these two changes my lifestyle is now pretty relaxed. I no longer feel I have to work here in Poland more like I work to go on holiday or work to buy a new floor for the kitchen.

Once more I will regurgitate a post I made a long time ago and I think it adequately answers the second question, ‚ÄòHow much do I need to earn in Poland‚Äô plus it will give many other perspective workers in Poland a figure that they should aim for. Basically, If you earn 710PLN per week you will survive. You can buy some ciggies, drink a few beers, maybe even be able to save some away and importantly, not live in a complete shit hole. But saying that, If you plan to live in Poland long term you need to adjust your sights somewhat and aim for around 1000PLN per week. However you need to then increase that figure if you will factor children or a car into the equation.

I remember when I first started in Poland that figure was the holy grail for me and other teachers, and it seemed a little unrealistic to achieve. We all heard the rumours of English teachers who worked for themselves and earned 1000PLN per week and thought they were either fictitious or living the life of riley. But I will say this, If you work hard in Poland and continue to develop yourself (Even as an English teacher) there is no reason why you can‚Äôt earn plus 0f 1000PLN per week or even more.

For those interested below is my original attempt at tackling this subject; from around August 2010 (I think)

A very common question I get asked is ‚ÄòHow much money will I earn in Poland teaching English‚Äô‚Ä¶

I will try to answer it here using my Economics degree‚Ä¶

You will be working as a teacher and teachers are never rich, please bear that in mind! but it‚Äôs easily possible to earn a better than average income in Poland as a language teacher.

Look at this scenario‚Ä¶

Polish GDP per capita is somewhere around $11,000.

Ignore the bullshit about PPP or GDP being an unreal average income value, look at what this figure represent‚Ä¶ It is the sum of everything produced in Poland divided by the number of people living in Poland. Therefore it is the empirical average income and your best indicator as to what to aim for in terms of income.

let‚Äôs take that figure of $11,000 and turn in into PLN, using an exchange rate of 3.1 as an approximate 12 month average.

So $11.000 x 3.1 = 34,100PLN

divide that figure by 48 weeks ‚Äì the other four weeks of the year are your holiday üòâ

leaves 710PLN per week.

divide this figure by 25 hours per week, an average language teacher workload‚Ä¶

leaves 29PLN as an average lesson fee. Now check this figure by browsing on Ang.pl

and you will see that the average lesson fee is around 30PLN.

Market forces, supply and demand, whatever you want to call it, 710PLN is the figure I aim to earn every week and I do OK. If I want I nice holiday, I work a few more hours. Your ability to manipulate your workload is a useful luxury as an English teacher. Achieving an average lesson fee of 30PLN is easy to do also, in fact most hours you get working for a school will generate you between 40 and 60PLN per hour. You‚Äôll never be rich as an English teacher but maintaining a nice lifestyle with a little bit of effort is easy to do here in Poland.

Of course, depending on your lifestyle and location, you might need more or less money but 710PLN is the magic number for me and the magic number I quote to all the other newbies who ask. You might here stories of English teachers who earn 6k or 7k per month here in Poland, it‚Äôs possible to do, especially in Warsaw, but I bet they‚Äôll be working there arses off to achieve it. Once or twice over the past year I took home 6K in a month but I worked practically everyday to do it and it just isn‚Äôt necessary.

If everyweek you take home 710PLN, you‚Äôll do fine.

My first post on this matter was here

Zameldowanie and dreams of riches

which was back in 2009 when I dreamt up a crazy idea to make the British banking system even more fragile than it was using my shiny new Polish passport. I still don‚Äôt have the passport but I‚Äôm hoping it will change this year üôÇ

One of the first things you will need to do when you settle down in Poland is apply for your ‚ÄòAdres Zameldowania‚Äô. This is basically your ‚Äòofficial‚Äô address, and yes your actual address can be different but the government will generally communicate with you to your ‚Äòofficial‚Äô address. The idea is a communist relic but it serves a purpose today as being the governments way of communicating with you, serving official documents as well as being the first place they look if you‚Äôve been naughty.

Why do I need to get an ‚ÄòOfficial‚Äô address? Well, it shows the Polish government that you have somewhere to live and so they will grant you permanent residency (which I‚Äôll talk about in a later blog post) and secondly you need it in order to complete the correct tax registration. Also, I have read that without an official address you‚Äôre, in theory, required to pay tourist tax for everyday you‚Äôre in Poland, although of course this is impossible to prove ‚Äì many people survive in Poland without an official address but from my experience life is just easier if you have one. If your long term plans are in Poland and you‚Äôre thinking of a passport like me, it‚Äôs best to get it all over and done with.

You can read loads of blog posts and forums with commentary on the topic but the one flaw is that people assume their experiences are the ‚Äòcorrect‚Äô experiences however all newcomers to Poland should realise that bureaucratic procedures can vary immense between regions and tax authorities. So today I have tried to collate and collect all the best information possible to give newbies a fighting chance against Polish bureaucracy.

To get your Zameldowanie, you need to find someone that is willing to let you be registered officially at their house. There‚Äôs no requirements concerning who this person is or isn‚Äôt ‚Äì it can be anyone. But finding this person can be difficult because once you‚Äôre registered to one official address you always have right to abode and it can be difficult for the landlord to revoke this. For me, I used my father in law ‚Äì but I know others that have just paid random people for the permission.

Once you‚Äôve found this person ‚Äì you need to head to your local UrzƒÖd Miasta and go preferably with the landlord of the property you will become resident at. Take your passport with you and if you can take an extra body who can help translate between all the involved parties!

The main point of my story here is that there are many conflicting ideas to as of whether the landlord need to be there in person. In my experience they do so I think it‚Äôs just best to assume they are necessary than to have loads of wasted journeys.

Finally you need to do this in office hours so it can be challenging to get everyone in one place and be prepared to ask loads of random questions concerning you, your background and your family. And if your registering to an address in a small town or village don‚Äôt expect the person in the tax office to have any idea what to do. I remember when I first went to my local tax office and said I wanted to apply for an official address ‚Äì the women looked like I had just eaten her child or something‚Ä¶ pure terror.

Not long ago I added my email address to this blog so people could make contact and apart from the friendly ‚Äòhellos‚Äô (which I always enjoy) a few people have been asking more general questions about living in Poland.

Therefore, Welcome to my new series of posts titled

‚ÄúLiving in Poland tips for beginners‚Äù

First up ‚ÄòFinding a house‚Äô

Dan from Norwich ( I assume U.K.) ‚Äì asked ‚ÄòWhat are the best accommodation options for me if I‚Äôm thinking of moving to Poland? Where do I begin to look?‚Äò

0. Tip number ‚Äò0‚Äô is not even a tip, it‚Äôs common sense. Do your research first. Newspapers and the Internet will give you the background knowledge you need. Learning the absolute basic associated Polish words i.e. Dom, will also help you.

1. I would firstly recommend looking around at local Polish community websites where you live now. Most big citites or even small towns will have some kind of Polish community in the U.K. and obviously large cities in the U.S and other places will have the same. Go into Polish shops or look around in local newspapers. I remember when I lived in Stoke, quite a few Polish shops had a small notice board offering services or even accommodation back in Polska. It‚Äôs a good place to begin because odds are; you can meet somebody and arrange everything face to face PRIOR to leaving the country. So you get the peace of mind value. Plus you can find out about associated services such as movers or people with a van driving across the continent in your general direction.

2. Check out and post on sites like PolishForums. The community on sites like PF is pretty strong and is very regional. If you post a question about ‚ÄòLooking for a house in O≈Çawa‚Äô ‚Äì Somebody from O≈Çawa will point you in the best general direction to start. Try Facebook and search for ‚ÄòWroc≈Çaw expats‚Äô, ‚Äò≈Åodz expats‚Äô etc‚Ä¶ to find other online communities you can pester.

3. Consider ‚ÄòHostelling‚Äô for the first few weeks. This is a popular option by many people I know in Wroc≈Çaw. Come to Poland lightweight at first, stay in a hostel and then get your feet on the ground and talk to people. Meet other expats, meet the locals and ask if they know anybody. The friend of a friend scenario in Poland always works best and you can find yourself a reliable good deal this way or if you‚Äôre inclined, find accommodation with other expats with your native tongue‚Ä¶ If you don‚Äôt fancy jumping into the deep end straight away. When you‚Äôre in the city you want to live in, just by walking around and looking out for the little home-made ads on lampposts or notice boards will also be your best opportunity to find a good value room.

When everything is sorted, pop home and get ready for the big move.

4. Maybe you want to buy a house? If you have any kind of equity from your home country, it‚Äôs possible to find a very cheap but decent home in Poland. In my experience villages offer the lowest house prices (plus a more authentic cultural experience). This option may be suitable for people wanting to live in Poland for the longer term but obviously there is shit loads more hassle and worry involved. But it‚Äôs possible. And I dare say 30% of the expats I know here are all fully fledged home owners. Companies like ‚ÄòConnect Overseas‚Äô will help you with the finance as for the paperwork‚Ä¶ I have no good advice, get the help of a local lawyer then grin and bare it.

5. Advice on Price. This is impossible to give because in varies wildly. From my experience, last year I rented a two bed room apartment in a town for 700PLN but I know people who rent shared rooms in big cities and pay 500PLN. Generally, I think it‚Äôs easily possible to find yourself a nice place in big cities for around 1500PLN but you need to add another 500PLN for rates. But everything is subjective; my idea of nice might be your idea of shit or even luxurious.

Warsaw will obviously be the most expensive and generally, the further east you go the cheaper (everything) gets.

There you have it, my advice for newbies but as this is a dynamic blog (or I like to think it is), If any readers want to contradict or share there experience, please feel free.

The Immam let us have a good look round despite being underdressed and 50% female

To begin with, if you want to read a good blog post about expat Englishmen in Egypt,

EDIM already beat me to it here:

Snow to Sand

For me, going to Egypt was a chance to have a well deserved break in the sun and to learn a bit about a new country, culture and to suss out any potential teaching opportunities‚Ä¶ should I need to leave Poland in a hurry üòâ

Quite a few peeps have commented that I must be crazy to go there now but let‚Äôs be realistic: no body wants tourists to be hurt.

In Egypt I tried to pass myself off as a Polish man because things are inevitably cheaper if you say you‚Äôre Polish and not English. Russians are not well liked in Egypt because they are seen as being rude which I kind of understand but also think it‚Äôs a bit harsh. English people are seen as drunkards which is true, Americans as cowards because they have all disappeared since the ‚Äòcrisis‚Äô but Polish people are seen to be people Egyptians have a shared history with. Years of oppression overturned by protesting and the hopes of a bright future powered by European economies.

From my perspective as a fake Pole Englishman. The closest correlation I saw between Egyptian culture and Polish culture was the fact that both are hardcore workaholics. Sorry for these generalisations but it has to be said, I saw the similarities.

It‚Äôs also pretty clear to see that Murbarak was/is hated by everybody on the street. Without fail through the hundreds of people I spoke to in a bizarre mixture of English/Polish and Arabic everyone said that Murbarak going was a good thing. The picture to the left was given to me buy someone I spoke to, it celebrates the revolution and for some reason blogger won‚Äôt let me orientate it correctly

APC ‚Äì for traffic control and sun shelter

In terms of the army. They seem to have everything under control. Movement is monitored by checkpoints on the edge of all cities and towns but the army rarely bothers any form of transport carrying tourists. Taxis and minibuses are often spot checked by uniformed or plain clothes Police officers giving the overall all round effect of feeling quite safe.

The only unusual thing I thought was that our hotel had a sort of security procedure similar to an airport with a metal detector and a pat down. Sometimes they just waved us through but once or twice we had to do the procedure properly. I‚Äôm not entirely sure what they were expecting to find on us tourists but hey ho, it all added to the sense of adventure.

We had planned on doing a lot of travelling but that went to pot when I realised how luxurious life can be in an all-inclusive resort with limitless beer but we did get out and about for a few days. Heading west towards Libya was not an option because travelling through Cairo takes a long time so we headed north towards Israel and Jordan (subject of a future post). The biggest benefit of travelling outside of the cosy resorts is the fact you can really see the level of development. In some places the standard of living was shocking.

Really shocking.

2$ a day is what the average Egyptian lives on and when you see all the tourists and the Suez canal ‚Äì you begin to see why people got cheesed off. Egyptians should be rolling in cash. The people who have jobs in the resorts are the lucky ones. They have health care, free holidays (at other resorts) and the possibilities of tips from tourists but for everyone else‚Ä¶it‚Äôs a pretty bleak, dog eat dog world.

The haggling for absolutely everything you buy would be the main reason why teaching in Egypt would be a problem. Everyone would constantly take you for a tourist and try to charge some ludicrous price like the guy in the petrol station who tried to make me pay 10$ for 1.5l of Pepsi. If you wanted to be a teacher I‚Äôm not sure who would pay you. I mean a lot of the rich people in Egypt now are slightly pre-occupied with where the hammer will fall next although I‚Äôm sure in Cairo you could find easy work. But aside from the rich people, everybody else just couldn‚Äôt afford your services. If you earn 2$ a days how much can you spare for an English teacher?

Although I have to say, In a few years and if Egypt does begin to develop‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll head out there like a shot. I can‚Äôt imagine how good my tan will be after a few months living out there. I have found a few job adverts online for English teachers claiming to pay 500$ (in Egypt you would live very well) but obviously they are for international schools and I‚Äôm not sure how recent or genuine they are.

Finally, I have had the good fortune to have visited many places in our small world but Egypt would definitely be a place I would return to. Good people, Good weather.

Prior to flying out to Egypt, I had the chance to spend 1 day walking around Warsaw, the often underrated capital city of my beloved Polska. So this post is for anybody who is new to Warsaw or finds themselves unexpectedly in said city with a few hours to spare and wants to see some interesting stuff.

The DYSP Tour of Warsaw‚Ä¶

Icon of Warsaw: The palace of Culture and Science

1.Warsawa Centralna: Start off by grabbing a quick beer in the underground maze of shops, bars and coffeeshops at the train station. If you have a lot of cash to burn you can go to the huge shopping centre next door and when you‚Äôre poor again you can head outside and take in a good look of the Pa≈Çac Kultury i Nauki: the symbol of Warsaw and a gift from Uncle Stalin‚Ä¶ for free.

2. Head North to Ul. Pr√≥zna: This street has been left more or less exactly the same as it was in WWII. Fresh with shrapnel scars etc‚Ä¶ interesting and eerie.

3. Head North East to Plac. Pi≈Çsudskiego: Here you can see the tomb of the Unknown Soldier which appears to be constantly guarded and nearby is the University and Ogr√≥d Saski, which is a good place to drink a takeaway coffee early in the morning.

4. Head North along Krakowskie Przedmie≈õcie: Along this route you can see the beautiful Hotel Bristol and the slightly boring Presidential Palace.

5. Continue North into the Old town: This is the more touristy part of Warsaw. Good place to buy souvenirs and see some of the medieval architecture.

Ciekawy‚Ä¶no?‚Ä¶

6. Head East along Most ≈ölƒÖsko past the Zoo. Metropolitan Orthodox Cathedral of St. Mary Magdalene ‚Äì cathedral of Polish Orthodox Church in Warsaw built in second half of XIX century: For me this is the best thing in Warsaw. The church looks exactly like orthodox churches I associate with Russia and is genuinely a beautiful sight to behold. Also the area you are now in is called Praga, where you can visit the Zoo and take a cheap dinner in the shopping centre opposite the church.

7. Catch the tram south to Park ≈Åazienkowski: This is the part of the journey most suitable for couples looking to indulge in a bit of romance. You can take a walk through the park and take a look at the squirrels (everyone loves squirrels) and I remember peacocks in the park and a floating palace but more importantly, a good place to buy waffles. Close by is the British Embassy and also in the park is a quite interesting Chopin monument.

8. Take a slow walk North back to Warsawa Centralna: Along the way north from the park I remember seeing a ‚Äògenuine‚Äô British fish and chip shop which might interest the Brits but for others I also remember a place where you can buy a beer for 5pln‚Ä¶ keep your eyes open.

9. Arrive at Warsaw train station i.e. Warsawa Centralna.

So, that‚Äôs it, my tour. I‚Äôm not saying that everything to see in Warsaw is here or that my route is good/optimal/interesting in anyway, but it was to route I took.

I‚Äôm also welcome to any other suggestions or amendments people might want to suggest.

Generally, people I have spoken to don‚Äôt like Warsaw because it‚Äôs a cold place full of unfriendly people and it‚Äôs style is some crazy mix of the old and the new. Well, In my opinion all capital cities fall into these traps but Warsaw has something else, notably interesting churches, communist towers and cheap beer! enjoy!
